class="mck-u-links-inline">The United States has committed to 100 percent zero-emission truck sales by 2040, but what needs to happen on the ground?</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div class="mck-o-sidebar mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Ftravel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure%2Four%20insights%2Fpowering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure%2Fpowering-the-transition-to-zero-emission-trucks-through-infrastructure.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="powering-the-transition-to-zero-emission-trucks-through-infrastructure" data-layer-report-name="powering-the-transition-to-zero-emission-trucks-through-infrastructure>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (8 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div></div>

<p><strong>Around seven million medium- and heavy-duty freight trucks</strong> circulate the United States today‚Äîand almost all are powered by traditional internal combustion engines (ICEs).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e32e01e1-2cad-4a8f-bce2-b9c59c028697"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e32e01e1-2cad-4a8f-bce2-b9c59c028697" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">IHS Automotive, AutoInsight, May 2022; EV-volumes, February 2022; McKinsey Center of Future Mobility Electrification Model, June 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> This legion of vehicles generates more than 25 percent of total greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) from the transportation sector, including carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides, pollutants that threaten the population‚Äôs respiratory and cardiovascular health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a2a2486e-199b-4d9d-890b-218630297a9f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a2a2486e-199b-4d9d-890b-218630297a9f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúSmog, soot, and other air pollution from transportation,‚Äù United States Environmental Protection Agency, January 4, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As truck transport continues to grow‚Äîwith about 65 percent of freight tonnage expected to be shipped by truck in 2050‚Äîemissions grow as well.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8b4838a9-1709-4edc-8f15-e8f55170008a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8b4838a9-1709-4edc-8f15-e8f55170008a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúFreight analysis framework,‚Äù United States Department of Transportation‚ÄîFederal Highway Administration, February 1, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The United States faces a transition point where it must move toward renewable energy and zero-emission vehicles (ZEVs).  Unlike their ICE counterparts, zero-emission (ZE) trucks, such as battery electric vehicles (BEV) or fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEV) powered by hydrogen, do not produce direct tailpipe emissions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d55d1fe-2886-4079-b07c-9dc16e0d0790"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d55d1fe-2886-4079-b07c-9dc16e0d0790" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The requirement to transition to ZE trucks may increase in importance if widespread adoption of commercialized autonomous technology furthers the cost-efficiency of autonomous vehicles (AVs), driving significant increases in the number of miles driven by AV trucks, leading to even higher emissions than currently projected.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In November 2022, the United States committed that ZE truck sales nationwide would reach 100 percent in 2040.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="65a4671b-32d9-4608-a8d2-cf5fde9f97c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="65a4671b-32d9-4608-a8d2-cf5fde9f97c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúU.S. signs global commitment to 100 percent zero-emission trucks, buses at COP27,‚Äù Environmental Defense Fund, November 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Thus, we expect the share of ZE trucks in operation to grow from less than 1 percent today to more than 75 percent in 2050 for all medium- and heavy-duty trucks. This shift could result in a roughly 20 percent reduction of GHG truck emissions by 2035 and more than 75 percent by 2050.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="53caf764-8546-41d7-808f-c24ff01c5fb2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="53caf764-8546-41d7-808f-c24ff01c5fb2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Center of Future Mobility Emissions Model, January 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Given the transport sector‚Äôs significant GHG emissions, a switch to ZE trucks could rev up the country‚Äôs drive to be cleaner and greener, with a better overall cost of ownership to fleet operators.</p>
<p>The opportunity for the freight truck sector to decarbonize now, and the ensuing impact on the economy and emissions, is enormous; however, a mass rollout of ZE trucks would require appropriate infrastructure to support commercial freight journeys, much like ICE vehicles need gas stations along their routes. Thus, we are faced with a chicken-and-egg problem. What comes first‚Äîthe ZE trucks or the refueling and charging stations that support them? Battery electric and fuel cell trucks need a minimum charging and refueling network to operate, but is it reasonable to invest heavily in infrastructure without a current demand to sustain (or even use) it?</p>
<p>This article examines how the most critical freight journeys can be used to map a minimum viable infrastructure network to support the ZE truck transition, outlining what the network needs to look like in 2050. Laying this groundwork could instill confidence in fleet operators and truck original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) to make the ZEV transition happen at pace and demonstrate the public sector‚Äôs commitment to it, too.</p>
<p>McKinsey analyzed today‚Äôs freight traffic in the United States and projected how it may change in the decades ahead. By analyzing trip characteristics and powertrain needs, we were then able to map the flow of trucks by ICE, BEV, or FCEV and thus plot out the optimal state-by-state distribution of refueling or charging stations required to keep each running.</p>
<p>Now is the time for public sector entities, private stakeholders, and fleet owners to start laying the groundwork for future ZE freight transport in earnest. Achieving their transition goals may require ten to 20 years of infrastructure development, an undertaking that demands a coordinated effort from the outset. We hope that aggregating cross-industry insights across all these stakeholder sets will help accelerate decarbonization by giving private and public entities a look at how the future may play out.</p>
<h2>ZE truck adoption is gathering speed as the public and private sectors set transition targets</h2>
<p>It is likely that ZE trucks will dominate future freight flows in the United States. Federal and state governments have already introduced regulations and incentives to promote the transition. Actions at the federal level include incentive programs and tax breaks for ZE vehicles, components, and infrastructure, tightened fleet emission standards, and adjusted expectations for net-zero fleet availability. The 2021 Bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, for instance, allocates $7.5 billion to charging infrastructure in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a9722844-56a3-4b45-8cd4-d566953657dd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a9722844-56a3-4b45-8cd4-d566953657dd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúFact sheet: Biden-Harris administration announces new standards and major progress for a made-in-America national network of electric vehicle chargers,‚Äù The White House, February 15, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Meanwhile, the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act unlocks tax credits for the purchase of commercial ZE trucks and the installation of charging infrastructure, providing grants for existing vehicle manufacturers to refit their facilities with ZEV-manufacturing equipment.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3d07515b-8b3c-4fb3-8746-ff8be922af26"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3d07515b-8b3c-4fb3-8746-ff8be922af26" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúClean heavy-duty vehicle program,‚Äù United States Environmental Protection Agency, February 13, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>State governments are complementing these measures by setting targets for the number of ZE trucks operating on their roads and banning ICE vehicles from entering in the future. California‚Äôs recent Advanced Clean Truck regulation, for example, requires manufacturers of commercial vehicles to start selling ZE trucks in 2024, with a goal to transition the state‚Äôs truck fleets to 100 percent ZE by 2045.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4230d4e9-6ee8-4791-b543-755ddaf6ee59"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4230d4e9-6ee8-4791-b543-755ddaf6ee59" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúUpdate: California's heavy-duty electrification regulations now adopted by 5 more states,‚Äù Mobility Notes, January 6, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In the private sector, auto manufacturers such as General Motors have announced plans to phase out ICE vehicle production, while companies such as Walmart and Unilever have announced emission reduction plans for their fleets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="04e1fe9a-5bd7-46c0-bdc9-8181ac612e17"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="04e1fe9a-5bd7-46c0-bdc9-8181ac612e17" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Neal E. Boudette and Coral Davenport, ‚ÄúG.M. will sell only zero-emission vehicles by 2035,‚Äù <em>New York Times</em>, January 28, 2021; Fernando Cortes, ‚ÄúZero sum: How Walmart transportation is working to reduce emissions now and in the future,‚Äù Walmart, June 8, 2022; ‚ÄúHow we‚Äôre driving down our logistics emissions,‚Äù Unilever, January 11, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex1-v4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="ICE trucks could be phased out of freight sales by 2050." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex1-v4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Mapping truck freight flows in the United States</h2>
<p>Freight routes are crucial conduits in the United States economy. Understanding the purpose of freight allows us to connect the flow of goods to route and traffic requirements in 2050, which informs the mix of powertrains required to sustain these future routes. This powertrain mix can then be used to calculate the infrastructure requirements to support these ZEV trucks.</p>
<p>To visualize current freight flows, we used the McKinsey Center for Future Mobility freight projections to map commodity flows and origin-destination city pairs onto state-by-state vehicle traffic. As expected, heavy-duty trucks (HDTs) are currently concentrated in the Midwest and along transcontinental corridors, while medium-duty trucks (MDTs) operate chiefly within regional corridors between large urban areas (Exhibit 2).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ed5a6858-c408-4280-95e8-d77eaf9edbf9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ed5a6858-c408-4280-95e8-d77eaf9edbf9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Vehicle traffic from HPMS and commodity flows from FWHA‚Äôs FAF.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex2-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="MDTs are concentrated on urban roads between big metropolitan areas, while HDTs are mostly found on connecting interstates." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex2-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Building on this visualization, commodity growth projections were used to map out how the distribution and volume of HDTs and MDTs might evolve in the future, completing the image of what freight flows could look like by 2050. As the transition toward ZE trucks picks up speed, freight flow visualizations suggest the coverage that ZE infrastructure would likely need to deliver (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex3-v4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="BEVs are expected to be more prevalent in regional truck corridors, while FCEVs will predominate in long-haul truck routes." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex3-v4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Matching freight journeys to vehicle powertrains</h2>
<p>A closer examination of trip characteristics provides further information on the type of ZE powertrains (either BEV or FCEV) that are expected to traverse established freight routes in the future and the infrastructure needed to support them‚Äîwhether electric vehicle charging infrastructure (EVCI) for BEV trucks or hydrogen refueling stations (HRS) for FCEV trucks.</p>
<p>The analysis for this article allows us to determine the optimal ZE truck powertrain according to distance, range, charging time, and truck characteristics based on today‚Äôs assumptions of tomorrow‚Äôs technical capabilities. Let‚Äôs look at two route examples: San Francisco to Los Angeles and San Francisco to New York (Exhibit 4).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex4-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="BEV trucks will suit shorter deliveries of lighter commodities, while FCEV trucks are better prepared for longer travel with heavier loads." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex4-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>BEV would be the optimal powertrain choice for a typical San Francisco to Los Angeles trip. On this shorter route frequently populated by MDTs, increased availability of electricity may make fuel costs more competitive when compared to ICEs and FCEVs. Battery range could also allow a full trip without stops, which is important due to BEV's slower charging time.</p>
<p>On the longer San Francisco to New York trip, FCEV may be the ideal powertrain match. FCEV‚Äôs higher range means fewer stops, and quicker FCEV refueling times are estimated to reduce journey times by 25 percent. Though the fuel cost is slightly higher, the faster delivery time and labor savings point to FCEV being more efficient than BEV for this trip.</p>
<p>Equipped with this information, we can begin to map out the demand for charging and refueling hubs along established freight routes, ensuring that infrastructure is built to support types of ZE trucks and the volume of traffic in the decades to come.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients">Travel, Logistics & Infrastructure Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<h2>How many charging and refueling stations will be needed to support the switch?</h2>
<p>The shift toward ZE trucks may require sizable investment in public charging and refueling infrastructure. Drawing on freight flow projections, and layering on expected powertrain adoption plus energy requirements, we estimated the number of public HRS and EVCI stations that will likely be required to keep ZE trucks running in the future (Exhibit 5). Overall, investing in these stations for US HDT and MDT could result in a total capital expenditure of about $20-30 billion (construction cost only).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="046e8001-52cf-4a70-be82-b3958b871079"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="046e8001-52cf-4a70-be82-b3958b871079" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In 2023 dollars, excludes any potential hydrogen production/compression and grid upgrades or any operational costs.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In addition to these estimates, it is likely that complementary infrastructure such as grid upgrades and hydrogen compression and distribution investments will be necessary.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex5-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="California, Texas, and the Midwest will have the highest ZE truck infrastructure demand and cumulative capital expenditure from 2022-50." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/powering%20the%20transition%20to%20zero%20emission%20trucks%20through%20infrastructure/svgz-powering-transition-zero-emission-trucks-ex5-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Major trends that could impact ZE truck and infrastructure projections</h2>
<p>There are four major disruptions that could significantly change the evolution of the ZE truck market in the next few decades (and thus these projections)‚Äîwith implications for the type and volume of powertrains expected on freight routes, and the demand for public charging and refueling stations:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Nearshoring and regionalization: Multiple factors, such as supply shortages, transport difficulties, and a focus on sustainability, have led to an increased focus on nearshoring and regionalization. Over the next few decades, this may alter how cargo volumes are distributed between water and land ports. Increased prevalence of regional trips and a decrease in long-haul use cases may also lead to higher utilization of BEV trucks compared to FCEV trucks.</li>
    <li>Autonomous trucking: Autonomous trucks are being developed for middle-mile land transport, typically for trips between warehouses. Without the need for driver breaks, long-haul trips become quicker and more economical. Therefore, their frequency compared to regional and urban trips is likely to increase. Utilizing FCEV technology will further this efficiency gain, as hydrogen refueling is markedly quicker than BEV. Thus autonomous technology may help accelerate FCEV adoption. Given the decrease in long-haul trip time, frequency of long-haul trips will likely increase, compared to urban and regional distances.</li>
    <li>Changes to the value chain: Beneficial cargo owners (BCOs), such as e-commerce companies with their own distribution fleets, and companies with platform-based digital business models may have a major impact on the traditional value chain, as BCOs own large fleets and tend to rely on private infrastructure. As BCOs grow, fleet owners may increasingly utilize their own private charging or refueling stations, which could open up space at existing public stations.</li>
    <li>Cargo drones: The use of commercial unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for last-mile and remote delivery would require a new class of infrastructure including vertiports, airports, and UAV chargers. This may capture volume from urban trips made by MDT today.</li>
    <li>E-fuels: E-fuels are synthetic fuels created from previously captured CO<sub>2</sub>. The combustion of e-fuel, which can be used to power ICE engines, still results in tailpipe emissions. Due to their overall CO<sub>2</sub>-neutral balance, however, there is currently a push in certain European nations to extend synthetic fuel production and usage. Acceptance of this fuel for US renewable efforts‚Äîlikely dependent on the extent to which emissions from the use of e-fuel align with US regulatory standards‚Äîmay increase the prevalence of ICE vehicles in our projections and reduce the need for EVCI or HRS.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="621da12b-0b27-4062-8fdf-b8b5e265e4e5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="621da12b-0b27-4062-8fdf-b8b5e265e4e5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">William Wilkes and Wilfried Eckl-Dorna, ‚ÄúPorsche, Ferrari e-fuel push at heart of EU engine debate,‚Äù <em>Bloomberg,</em> March 4, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<h2>The rollout of ZE infrastructure is a shared undertaking</h2>
<p>Both the public and private sector have a role to play in establishing future ZE infrastructure. While the public sector could focus on the supporting infrastructure, industry collaboration, and social development, private stakeholders may consider thinking through product development, investments, and operations.</p>
<h3>What is required from the public sector to enable this transition?</h3>
<p>Governments could consider several important questions to enhance and support the ZE truck transition, including:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Can power grids consistently deliver large volumes of electricity at high rates, or will they need to be upgraded as chargers scale and become faster?</li>
    <li>How do governments enable the back-end infrastructure of hydrogen refueling stations at scale, given limited use today?</li>
    <li>How can government agencies aim to work with private stakeholders, encouraging the ZEV transition but also creating self-sustainable businesses?</li>
    <li>How can the planning and development of highways, roads, and bridges change as vehicle characteristics evolve with ZEVs (for example, the introduction of heavy batteries affecting road maintenance and bridge weight thresholds)?</li>
    <li>How can states encourage job creation in their region as a part of the ZEV transition and infrastructure buildout?</li>
</ul>
<h3>What is required from the private sector to enable this transition?</h3>
<p>The private sector may also play a major role in achieving a ZEV transition, fueled by both regulatory and consumer pressure. The private sector could consider reflecting on key questions when working towards ZE truck transition, including:</p>
<ul>
    <li>As commodity producers‚Äô freight volumes grow, how might their technology requirements evolve to meet this increased demand for product transport?</li>
    <li>How can ZE truck manufacturers think through their development timelines and the mix of powertrains in production?</li>
    <li>How can EVCI and HRS operators decide where to locate their charging stations and how to work with state and local governments?</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The public and private sectors are already edging towards a zero-emissions future, but revving up a ZE freight network demands immediate and coordinated action. Building and planning ZE infrastructure requires substantial time and investment, and the United States‚Äô goal to halt the sale of ICE trucks by 2040 looms closer. Understanding the scope of the challenge should be the first stop, as mapping current routes will make clear what is required to power freight fleets of the future. Keeping an eye on technological developments is also necessary, to ensure the sector avoids any blind spots. Starting now, a clear map, a smart inventory of tools, and the backing of a determined collective could put the United States well on its way to an emissions-free 2050 destination.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/andreas-breiter">Andreas Breiter</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey‚Äôs Silicon Valley office, <strong>Peter Fr√∂de</strong> is an associate partner in the Los Angeles office, and <strong>Vineet Jain</strong> is a consultant in the San Francisco office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/shannon-peloquin">Shannon Peloquin</a></strong> is a partner.</p>

1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAround seven million medium- and heavy-duty freight trucks\u003c/strong\u003e circulate the United States today\u0026mdash;and almost all are powered by traditional internal combustion engines (ICEs).[[footnote 1]] This legion of vehicles generates more than 25 percent of total greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) from the transportation sector, including carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides, pollutants that threaten the population\u0026rsquo;s respiratory and cardiovascular health.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs truck transport continues to grow\u0026mdash;with about 65 percent of freight tonnage expected to be shipped by truck in 2050\u0026mdash;emissions grow as well.[[footnote 3]] The United States faces a transition point where it must move toward renewable energy and zero-emission vehicles (ZEVs).  Unlike their ICE counterparts, zero-emission (ZE) trucks, such as battery electric vehicles (BEV) or fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEV) powered by hydrogen, do not produce direct tailpipe emissions.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn November 2022, the United States committed that ZE truck sales nationwide would reach 100 percent in 2040.[[footnote 5]] Thus, we expect the share of ZE trucks in operation to grow from less than 1 percent today to more than 75 percent in 2050 for all medium- and heavy-duty trucks. This shift could result in a roughly 20 percent reduction of GHG truck emissions by 2035 and more than 75 percent by 2050.[[footnote 6]] Given the transport sector\u0026rsquo;s significant GHG emissions, a switch to ZE trucks could rev up the country\u0026rsquo;s drive to be cleaner and greener, with a better overall cost of ownership to fleet operators.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe opportunity for the freight truck sector to decarbonize now, and the ensuing impact on the economy and emissions, is enormous; however, a mass rollout of ZE trucks would require appropriate infrastructure to support commercial freight journeys, much like ICE vehicles need gas stations along their routes. Thus, we are faced with a chicken-and-egg problem. What comes first\u0026mdash;the ZE trucks or the refueling and charging stations that support them? Battery electric and fuel cell trucks need a minimum charging and refueling network to operate, but is it reasonable to invest heavily in infrastructure without a current demand to sustain (or even use) it?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article examines how the most critical freight journeys can be used to map a minimum viable infrastructure network to support the ZE truck transition, outlining what the network needs to look like in 2050. Laying this groundwork could instill confidence in fleet operators and truck original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) to make the ZEV transition happen at pace and demonstrate the public sector\u0026rsquo;s commitment to it, too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey analyzed today\u0026rsquo;s freight traffic in the United States and projected how it may change in the decades ahead. By analyzing trip characteristics and powertrain needs, we were then able to map the flow of trucks by ICE, BEV, or FCEV and thus plot out the optimal state-by-state distribution of refueling or charging stations required to keep each running.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow is the time for public sector entities, private stakeholders, and fleet owners to start laying the groundwork for future ZE freight transport in earnest. Achieving their transition goals may require ten to 20 years of infrastructure development, an undertaking that demands a coordinated effort from the outset. We hope that aggregating cross-industry insights across all these stakeholder sets will help accelerate decarbonization by giving private and public entities a look at how the future may play out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eZE truck adoption is gathering speed as the public and private sectors set transition targets\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt is likely that ZE trucks will dominate future freight flows in the United States. Federal and state governments have already introduced regulations and incentives to promote the transition. Actions at the federal level include incentive programs and tax breaks for ZE vehicles, components, and infrastructure, tightened fleet emission standards, and adjusted expectations for net-zero fleet availability. The 2021 Bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, for instance, allocates $7.5 billion to charging infrastructure in the United States.[[footnote 7]] Meanwhile, the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act unlocks tax credits for the purchase of commercial ZE trucks and the installation of charging infrastructure, providing grants for existing vehicle manufacturers to refit their facilities with ZEV-manufacturing equipment.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eState governments are complementing these measures by setting targets for the number of ZE trucks operating on their roads and banning ICE vehicles from entering in the future. California\u0026rsquo;s recent Advanced Clean Truck regulation, for example, requires manufacturers of commercial vehicles to start selling ZE trucks in 2024, with a goal to transition the state\u0026rsquo;s truck fleets to 100 percent ZE by 2045.[[footnote 9]] In the private sector, auto manufacturers such as General Motors have announced plans to phase out ICE vehicle production, while companies such as Walmart and Unilever have announced emission reduction plans for their fleets.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eMapping truck freight flows in the United States\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFreight routes are crucial conduits in the United States economy. Understanding the purpose of freight allows us to connect the flow of goods to route and traffic requirements in 2050, which informs the mix of powertrains required to sustain these future routes. This powertrain mix can then be used to calculate the infrastructure requirements to support these ZEV trucks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo visualize current freight flows, we used the McKinsey Center for Future Mobility freight projections to map commodity flows and origin-destination city pairs onto state-by-state vehicle traffic. As expected, heavy-duty trucks (HDTs) are currently concentrated in the Midwest and along transcontinental corridors, while medium-duty trucks (MDTs) operate chiefly within regional corridors between large urban areas (Exhibit 2).[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding on this visualization, commodity growth projections were used to map out how the distribution and volume of HDTs and MDTs might evolve in the future, completing the image of what freight flows could look like by 2050. As the transition toward ZE trucks picks up speed, freight flow visualizations suggest the coverage that ZE infrastructure would likely need to deliver (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch2\u003eMatching freight journeys to vehicle powertrains\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA closer examination of trip characteristics provides further information on the type of ZE powertrains (either BEV or FCEV) that are expected to traverse established freight routes in the future and the infrastructure needed to support them\u0026mdash;whether electric vehicle charging infrastructure (EVCI) for BEV trucks or hydrogen refueling stations (HRS) for FCEV trucks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe analysis for this article allows us to determine the optimal ZE truck powertrain according to distance, range, charging time, and truck characteristics based on today\u0026rsquo;s assumptions of tomorrow\u0026rsquo;s technical capabilities. Let\u0026rsquo;s look at two route examples: San Francisco to Los Angeles and San Francisco to New York (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eBEV would be the optimal powertrain choice for a typical San Francisco to Los Angeles trip. On this shorter route frequently populated by MDTs, increased availability of electricity may make fuel costs more competitive when compared to ICEs and FCEVs. Battery range could also allow a full trip without stops, which is important due to BEV's slower charging time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the longer San Francisco to New York trip, FCEV may be the ideal powertrain match. FCEV\u0026rsquo;s higher range means fewer stops, and quicker FCEV refueling times are estimated to reduce journey times by 25 percent. Though the fuel cost is slightly higher, the faster delivery time and labor savings point to FCEV being more efficient than BEV for this trip.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquipped with this information, we can begin to map out the demand for charging and refueling hubs along established freight routes, ensuring that infrastructure is built to support types of ZE trucks and the volume of traffic in the decades to come.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHow many charging and refueling stations will be needed to support the switch?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe shift toward ZE trucks may require sizable investment in public charging and refueling infrastructure. Drawing on freight flow projections, and layering on expected powertrain adoption plus energy requirements, we estimated the number of public HRS and EVCI stations that will likely be required to keep ZE trucks running in the future (Exhibit 5). Overall, investing in these stations for US HDT and MDT could result in a total capital expenditure of about $20-30 billion (construction cost only).[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to these estimates, it is likely that complementary infrastructure such as grid upgrades and hydrogen compression and distribution investments will be necessary.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003ch2\u003eMajor trends that could impact ZE truck and infrastructure projections\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are four major disruptions that could significantly change the evolution of the ZE truck market in the next few decades (and thus these projections)\u0026mdash;with implications for the type and volume of powertrains expected on freight routes, and the demand for public charging and refueling stations:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eNearshoring and regionalization: Multiple factors, such as supply shortages, transport difficulties, and a focus on sustainability, have led to an increased focus on nearshoring and regionalization. Over the next few decades, this may alter how cargo volumes are distributed between water and land ports. Increased prevalence of regional trips and a decrease in long-haul use cases may also lead to higher utilization of BEV trucks compared to FCEV trucks.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAutonomous trucking: Autonomous trucks are being developed for middle-mile land transport, typically for trips between warehouses. Without the need for driver breaks, long-haul trips become quicker and more economical. Therefore, their frequency compared to regional and urban trips is likely to increase. Utilizing FCEV technology will further this efficiency gain, as hydrogen refueling is markedly quicker than BEV. Thus autonomous technology may help accelerate FCEV adoption. Given the decrease in long-haul trip time, frequency of long-haul trips will likely increase, compared to urban and regional distances.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eChanges to the value chain: Beneficial cargo owners (BCOs), such as e-commerce companies with their own distribution fleets, and companies with platform-based digital business models may have a major impact on the traditional value chain, as BCOs own large fleets and tend to rely on private infrastructure. As BCOs grow, fleet owners may increasingly utilize their own private charging or refueling stations, which could open up space at existing public stations.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCargo drones: The use of commercial unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for last-mile and remote delivery would require a new class of infrastructure including vertiports, airports, and UAV chargers. This may capture volume from urban trips made by MDT today.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eE-fuels: E-fuels are synthetic fuels created from previously captured CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e. The combustion of e-fuel, which can be used to power ICE engines, still results in tailpipe emissions. Due to their overall CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e-neutral balance, however, there is currently a push in certain European nations to extend synthetic fuel production and usage. Acceptance of this fuel for US renewable efforts\u0026mdash;likely dependent on the extent to which emissions from the use of e-fuel align with US regulatory standards\u0026mdash;may increase the prevalence of ICE vehicles in our projections and reduce the need for EVCI or HRS.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe rollout of ZE infrastructure is a shared undertaking\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth the public and private sector have a role to play in establishing future ZE infrastructure. While the public sector could focus on the supporting infrastructure, industry collaboration, and social development, private stakeholders may consider thinking through product development, investments, and operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat is required from the public sector to enable this transition?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments could consider several important questions to enhance and support the ZE truck transition, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCan power grids consistently deliver large volumes of electricity at high rates, or will they need to be upgraded as chargers scale and become faster?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHow do governments enable the back-end infrastructure of hydrogen refueling stations at scale, given limited use today?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHow can government agencies aim to work with private stakeholders, encouraging the ZEV transition but also creating self-sustainable businesses?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHow can the planning and development of highways, roads, and bridges change as vehicle characteristics evolve with ZEVs (for example, the introduction of heavy batteries affecting road maintenance and bridge weight thresholds)?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHow can states encourage job creation in their region as a part of the ZEV transition and infrastructure buildout?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat is required from the private sector to enable this transition?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe private sector may also play a major role in achieving a ZEV transition, fueled by both regulatory and consumer pressure. The private sector could consider reflecting on key questions when working towards ZE truck transition, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAs commodity producers\u0026rsquo; freight volumes grow, how might their technology requirements evolve to meet this increased demand for product transport?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHow can ZE truck manufacturers think through their development timelines and the mix of powertrains in production?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHow can EVCI and HRS operators decide where to locate their charging stations and how to work with state and local governments?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe public and private sectors are already edging towards a zero-emissions future, but revving up a ZE freight network demands immediate and coordinated action. Building and planning ZE infrastructure requires substantial time and investment, and the United States\u0026rsquo; goal to halt the sale of ICE trucks by 2040 looms closer. Understanding the scope of the challenge should be the first stop, as mapping current routes will make clear what is required to power freight fleets of the future. Keeping an eye on technological developments is also necessary, to ensure the sector avoids any blind spots. Starting now, a clear map, a smart inventory of tools, and the backing of a determined collective could put the United States well on its way to an emissions-free 2050 destination.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-04-21T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIHS Automotive, AutoInsight, May 2022;
